title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement https://www.github.com/pepijn-devries/adfExplorer/DESCRIPTION. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Blosc Compression
text: input data type raw(), assumed encodes data type element typesize bytes long. data type can structured form data necessarily needs known. course need know structure need interpret data, ’s Blosc compressor. example compresses raw() data assuming data type 2 bytes long. Note length resulting data actually longer input data. compressor overhead. data set just small compared overhead. Can compress data types Blosc? Yes can. first encode binary form (raw()), instance r_to_dtype() method converts data raw() format. can also use dtype argument encode compress data one go. case need specify appropriate data type (\vignette("dtypes")). example shows encode numeric() values little-endian 16 bit floating point data ("<f2") compresses .
code: library(blosc) data_input <- as.raw(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4)) blosc_compress(data_input, typesize = 2) #>  [1] 02 01 12 02 08 00 00 00 08 00 00 00 18 00 00 00 01 02 03 04 01 02 03 04 ## The line below won't work as the default `typesize` (4) does ## not match with the dtype size (2) ## blosc_compress(iris$Petal.Length, dtype = "<f2")  ## Explicitely set the `typesize` to 2 compressed_iris <-   blosc_compress(iris$Petal.Length, typesize = 2, dtype = "<f2")

title: Blosc Compression
text: output always vector raw() data. Generally, output data smaller input data. exceptions. One seen , data set small comparison compressor overhead. Another case data just random, compressor algorithm simply can’t compress data. compressed form, data can longer interpreted directly. need decompress first (blosc_decompress()).

title: Blosc Compression
text: can pick several algorithms compress data: "blosclz", "lz4", "lz4hc", "zlib", "zstd". single algorithm always best performance (speed compression level). really depends data can tested trial error. can also lower compression level argument prefer speed compression level.

title: Blosc Compression
text: decompression function (blosc_decompress()) accepts raw() data compressed Blosc. doesn’t created R, can generated software using c-blosc library. don’t specify compression algorithm, typesize anything else. information embedded header raw input data.

title: Blosc Compression
text: don’t specify output type, decompression routine returns raw() data. remember iris length data compressed earlier? can simply decompress calling blosc_decompress(). works, got raw() data output. decompressor knows nothing data structure decompressed data. Since know encoded little-endian 16 bit floating point values ("<f2"), can specify . specified, function automatically decode data.
code: iris_length1 <- blosc_decompress(compressed_iris) head(iris_length1) #> [1] 99 3d 99 3d 33 3d iris_length2 <- blosc_decompress(compressed_iris, dtype = "<f2") hist(iris_length2)

what: What are Data Types (and Why Should You Care?)
title: Data Types
text: data type description information stored digitally format. context BLOSC compression relevant used compress arrays structured data. data structured described data type. use BLOSC R, also relevant, R (design) provides access limited number data types, importantly: raw(), logical(), integer(), numeric() complex(). find table typical storage formats converted R types. Therefore, probably need convert data type stored data something can handled R (vice versa). convenience functions r_to_dtype() dtype_to_r() handle conversions. Note functions provide exhaustive features, meant handle common conversions.

title: Data Types
text: package hand uses version 2 data type specifications, superseded version 3. ? old version used still includes endianness encoding compact. combination endianness version 3 types can easily annotated version 2 data types. conversion , implemented package.

title: Data Types
text: Data types represented code first character reflects byte order data (see Wikipedia article Endianness). second character reflects main type data (integer, floating point). following numerical characters indicate size (bytes) element. data types M (date time) m (delta time), specification also includes unit time used store information. table shows overview common types, converted R types, important notes consider converting data. examples encoding r data dtypes
code: library(blosc) r_to_dtype(c(TRUE, FALSE), "|b1") #> Warning: Data contains values equal to the value representing missing values! #> [1] 01 00 r_to_dtype(1L:4L, "|u1") #> [1] 01 02 03 04 r_to_dtype(c(1.4, 9.8e-6), "<f8") #>  [1] 66 66 66 66 66 66 f6 3f 33 76 78 be 55 8d e4 3e r_to_dtype(1+1i, "<c16") #>  [1] 00 00 00 00 00 00 f0 3f 00 00 00 00 00 00 f0 3f r_to_dtype(as.POSIXct("2023-06-23 15:32:19", tz = "UTC"), "<M8[ms]") #> [1] b8 83 e2 e8 88 01 00 00 r_to_dtype(as.difftime(1, units = "weeks"), "<m8[D]") #> [1] 07 00 00 00 00 00 00 00

title: Data Types
text: Beware encoding R types dtype, may lose precision. receive notification, responsibility. Loss precision happens data type use encoding less precise R’s native type. instance encode R numeric (64 bit floating point) dtype "<f2" (16 bit floating point). become apparent convert dtype back R type. examples lose precision: Note always need use identical dtype back-transform encoded data. Otherwise get nonsensical results.
code: ## Encoding numeric (64 bit) as a 16 bit float: r_to_dtype(0.123, "<f2") |>   dtype_to_r("<f2") #> [1] 0.1229858  ## Encoding a date-time object in whole hours ## as opposed to a floating point of seconds r_to_dtype(as.POSIXct("2024-05-31 19:58:01", tz = "UTC"), "<M8[h]") |>   dtype_to_r("<M8[h]") #> [1] "2024-05-31 19:00:00 UTC"

title: Data Types
text: storing raw data, may want reserve value represent missing values. also R NA values. software may use different values represent missing values. Also, data types insufficient storage capacity store R NA values examples show can use custom values prepresent missing values.
code: ## As `na_value` is not specified for `dtype_to_r()` ## and the NA value is masked to 8 bit, the `FALSE` ## value is mistakenly interpreted as `NA` r_to_dtype(c(TRUE, NA, FALSE, TRUE), "|b1", na_value = -1) |>   dtype_to_r("|b1") #> [1] TRUE TRUE   NA TRUE  ## This can be fixed by specifying `na_value` r_to_dtype(c(TRUE, NA, FALSE, TRUE), "|b1", na_value = -1) |>   dtype_to_r("|b1", na_value = -1) #> [1]  TRUE    NA FALSE  TRUE  ## If the `na_value` is not specified for `dtype_to_r()`, ## it will be taken literally r_to_dtype(c(1, NA, 4, 5), "<i4", na_value = -999) |>   dtype_to_r("<i4") #> [1]    1 -999    4    5  ## If the `na_value` is specified for `dtype_to_r()`, ## it will interpreted as NA r_to_dtype(c(1, NA, 4, 5), "<i4", na_value = -999) |>   dtype_to_r("<i4", na_value = -999) #> [1]  1 NA  4  5

title: Authors and Citation
text: Pepijn de Vries. Author, maintainer.

what: Compress and Decompress Data Using the BLOSC Library
title: Compress and Decompress Data Using the BLOSC Library
text: Blosc blocking, shuffling lossless compression algorithm. often used compress n-dimensional structured array data. applied (amongst others) geo-spatial zarr file format. package ports BLOSC compressors decompressors R.

title: Compress and Decompress Data Using the BLOSC Library
text: Install latest developmental version R-Universe: MacOS users may first need install system requirements installing package using:

title: Compress and Decompress Data Using the BLOSC Library
text: blosc package can uesd compress raw data, also vectors data types. example shows data volcano matrix can compressed blosc. Note 16 bit floating (<f2) point numbers used compression much less precise R’s native 64 bit floating point numbers. Nonetheless, particular case precision sufficient restore volcano data.
code: library(blosc)  volcano_compressed <-   blosc_compress(volcano, typesize = 2L, dtype = "<f2")  object.size(volcano_compressed) #> 6312 bytes object.size(volcano) #> 42672 bytes volcano_reconstructed <-   matrix(     blosc_decompress(volcano_compressed, dtype = "<f2"),     nrow(volcano),     ncol(volcano)   )  image(volcano_reconstructed, col = terrain.colors(24L))

title: Compress and Decompress Data Using the BLOSC Library
text: Big thanks Simon Urbanek assisting setting MacOS config.

what: blosc: Compress and Decompress Data Using the BLOSC Library — blosc-package
title: blosc: Compress and Decompress Data Using the BLOSC Library — blosc-package
text: Blosc blocking, shuffling lossless compression algorithm. often used compress n-dimensional structured array data. applied (amongst others) geo-spatial zarr file format. package can used decompress data compress data.

title: blosc: Compress and Decompress Data Using the BLOSC Library — blosc-package
text: Maintainer: Pepijn de Vries pepijn.devries@outlook.com (ORCID)

what: Compress and decompress with Blosc — blosc_compress
title: Compress and decompress with Blosc — blosc_compress
text: Use Blosc library compress decompress data.

title: Compress and decompress with Blosc — blosc_compress
code: blosc_compress(   x,   compressor = "blosclz",   level = 7L,   shuffle = "noshuffle",   typesize = 4L,   ... )  blosc_decompress(x, ...)

title: Compress and decompress with Blosc — blosc_compress
text: x case blosc_decompress(), x always raw data decompressed. Use ... arguments convert decompressed data specific data type. case blosc_compress(), x either raw data vector data compressed. latter case, need specify dtype (see r_to_dtype()) order convert data raw information first. See \vignette("blosc") details. compressor compression algorithm used. Can "blosclz", "lz4", "lz4hc", "zlib", "zstd". level integer indicating required level compression. Needs 0 (compression) 9 (maximum compression). shuffle shuffle filter activated compression. one "noshuffle", "shuffle", "bitshuffle". typesize BLOSC compresses arrays structured data. argument specifies size (integer) data structure / type bytes. Default 4L bytes (.e. 32 bits), suitable compressing 32 bit integers. ... Arguments passed r_to_dtype().

title: Compress and decompress with Blosc — blosc_compress
text: case blosc_compress() vector compressed raw data returned. case blosc_decompress() returns vector decompressed raw data. case dtype (see dtype_to_r()) specified, vector specified type returned.

title: Compress and decompress with Blosc — blosc_compress
code: my_dat        <- as.raw(sample.int(2L, 10L*1024L, replace = TRUE) - 1L) my_dat_out    <- blosc_compress(my_dat, typesize = 1L) my_dat_decomp <- blosc_decompress(my_dat_out)  ## After compressing and decompressing the data is the same as the original: all(my_dat == my_dat_decomp) #> [1] TRUE

what: Convert from or to ZARR data types — r_to_dtype
title: Convert from or to ZARR data types — r_to_dtype
text: Use ZARR V2.0 data types convert R native types raw data.

title: Convert from or to ZARR data types — r_to_dtype
code: r_to_dtype(x, dtype, na_value = NA, ...)  dtype_to_r(x, dtype, na_value = NA, ...)

title: Convert from or to ZARR data types — r_to_dtype
text: x Object converted dtype data type used encoding/decoding raw data. dtype code consisting least 3 characters. first character indicates endianness data: '<' (little-endian), '>' (big-endian), '|' (endianness relevant). second character represents main data type ('b' boolean (logical), '' signed integer, 'u' unsigned integer, 'f' floating point number, 'c' complex number). 'M' used date-time objects 'm' delta time (see difftime()). following characters numerical indicating byte size data type. example: dtype = "<f4" means 32 bit floating point number; dtype = "|b1" means 8 bit logical value. main types 'M' 'm' always ended time unit square brackets storing date time (difference). valid code "<M8[h]. details dtypes see ZARR V2.0 \vignette("dtypes"). na_value storing raw data, may want reserve value represent missing values. also R NA values. software may use different values represent missing values. Also, data types insufficient storage capacity store R NA values. Therefore, can use argument indicate value represent missing values. default uses R NA. set NULL, missing values just processed , without notice warning. details see \vignette("dtypes"). ... Ignored

title: Convert from or to ZARR data types — r_to_dtype
text: case r_to_dtype() vector encoded raw data returned. case dtype_to_r() vector R type (appropriate specified dtype) returned possible.

title: Convert from or to ZARR data types — r_to_dtype
text: One applications BLOSC compression ZARR, used store n-dimensional structured data. r_to_dtype() dtype_to_r() convenience functions allows convert common data types R native types. R natively supports logical() (actually stored 32 bit integer memory), integer() (signed 32 bit integers), numeric() (64 bit floating points) complex() (real imaginary component represented 64 bit floating point). R also complex classes, generally derivatives aforementioned types. functions documented attempt convert raw data R types (vice versa). 'dtypes' appropriate R type counterpart, conversions possible directly result error. details see \vignette("dtypes").

title: Convert from or to ZARR data types — r_to_dtype
text: Pepijn de Vries

title: Convert from or to ZARR data types — r_to_dtype
code: ## Encode volcano data to 16 bit floating point values volcano_encoded <-   r_to_dtype(volcano, dtype = "<f2")  ## Decode the volcano format to its original volcano_reconstructed <-   dtype_to_r(volcano_encoded, dtype = "<f2")  ## The reconstruction is the same as its original: all(volcano_reconstructed == volcano) #> [1] TRUE  ## Encode a numeric sequence with a missing value represented by -999 r_to_dtype(c(1, 2, 3, NA, 4), dtype = "<i2", na_value = -999) #>  [1] 01 00 02 00 03 00 19 fc 04 00

title: blosc 0.0.3.0002
text: Added support date-time delta time objects Improved test coverage Added vignettes

title: blosc 0.0.2
text: Encode decode specific data types Compress decompress data BLOSC
